Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Transport of inertial particles in time-dependent and stochastic flows
Award.AbstractNarration:
Objects in moving fluids rarely go with the flow. Instead they may sink, swim or steer in order to reach a destination, or they may respond to other influences, including their own sizes and shapes. Taking advantage of the ways that real objects interact with flows enables a wide range of important technologies. On small scales, micro robots may be steered inside the human body to perform surgery. On the largest scales, ocean drifters may efficiently monitor currents, marine life or global weather patterns. Each example presents challenges originating from the complex fluid flow patterns and from the difficulty in planning the most efficient navigation strategy. This project concentrates on the challenges of positioning autonomous vehicles in the ocean, where unpredictable and variable currents, seasonal variability, weather events, and other random influences must also be accounted for. Computer models of fluid flows and mathematical models of control will be combined to find optimal strategies to position autonomous ocean vehicles. Laboratory experiments will use precisely tuned fluid flows and remotely controlled particles to capture the important effects of the vehicles' mass, size, and shape. The project payoff is significant in that a better monitored ocean is advantageous to fishing and shipping, the military, and environmental monitoring. The project will involve and support undergraduate and graduate students in leading-edge research. Significantly, the student population at Montclair State University, and in particular, the Department of Mathematical Sciences, includes a substantial proportion who are members of groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines (including women and minorities) and the research program will leverage existing programs directed to these students. The outcome of the research will be disseminated through seminars, presentations at meetings, and publications in peer-reviewed journals.

In this project computer models of fluid flows and mathematical models of transport and control will be combined to find optimal control strategies for autonomous ocean vehicles, which will be modeled both as inertial and non-inertial objects. Laboratory experiments on precisely tuned flows and magnetically controlled particles will be used both to validate and guide the investigations. The goal is to use experimental and computed flow fields to identify critical transport features and integrate these features into control algorithms that optimally position particles. This project will improve transport control capabilities by developing models for transport and control of inertial objects in canonical flows subject to time-dependent and stochastic perturbations. Flow data will be generated by the numerical simulation of gyre flows, jets, and boundary currents. Inertial particles will be modeled directly using a state-of-the-art interfacial multi-phase numerical code. Laboratory experiments have been designed so that similar flows can be generated by reconfiguring the geometric forcing devices. Through high resolution particle imaging velocimetry (PIV) and particle tracking, experimental flow fields and their transport properties will be correlated with those of the associated model flows. Additionally, control strategies will be implemented using ferromagnetic tracer particles and magnetic pulses. To gain insight into the flow transport properties, flow and tracer data will be analyzed using a variety of geometric and probabilistic methods including finite-time Lyapunov exponents, inertial particle models, almost invariant sets, and finite-time coherent sets. These techniques will directly result in the ability to identify loitering regions and their boundaries and to determine maximal transport rates. This information will be leveraged to develop simple predictive models of transport and trajectory control that can be efficiently adapted to emergent applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project involved the theoretical, computational, and experimental study of the transport of inertial particles in geophysical flows. In particular, the project concentrated on the challenges of positioning autonomous vehicles in the ocean, where unpredictable and variable currents, seasonal variability, weather events, and other random influences must be accounted for to find optimal strategies to position autonomous ocean vehicles. The research has established new techniques for understanding material transport and for developing new control strategies. Important outcomes from the project include:

Improving Autonomy: We developed an information theoretic search strategy for single and multi-robot teams to localize the source of a chemical spill in turbulent flows. The robots rely on sporadic and  intermittent sensor readings to synthesize information maximizing exploration strategies. In addition, we showed how a geophysical description of the environmental dynamics can improve existing motion control strategies. This is especially true when process and vehicle dynamics are intricately coupled with the environmental dynamics. Since coherent structures enables the prediction and estimation of the environmental dynamics, we have demonstrated how this geophysical perspective can result in improved control strategies for autonomous systems.

Control of Gyre Transitions: We have developed a control strategy to control the inter-gyre switching time of an agent operating in a gyre flow. The proposed control strategy exploits the stochasticity of the underlying environment to affect inter-gyre transitions. We have shown how control can be used to enhance or abate the mean escape time and have developed a strategy to achieve a desired mean escape time. The proposed control strategy can achieve any desired escape time in an interval governed by the maximum available control.

Shaping Stochastic Escape and Switching: We developed a strategy to control the mean stochastic switching times of general dynamical systems with multiple equilibrium states subject to Gaussian white noise. The control can either enhance or abate the probability of escape from the deterministic region of attraction of a stable equilibrium in the presence of external noise. We have synthesized a feedback control strategy that actively changes the system's mean stochastic switching behavior based on the system's distance to the boundary of the attracting region. With the proposed controller, we are able to achieve a desired mean switching time, even when the strength of noise in the system is not known.  The control method has been analytically validated, and its effectiveness has been numerically demonstrated for a set of dynamical systems of practical importance.

Inertial FTLE: We have considered two types of geophysical flows, the classical double-gyre model, and a single-layer quasi-geostrophic PDE model, and have used finite-time Lyapunov exponents (FTLE) to characterize the attracting and repelling Lagrangian Coherent Structures (LCS) for these models. In particular, we have shown how inertial particles aggregate with respect to LCS. We have numerically investigate the dynamics of inertial particles for a range of Stokes numbers and density ratios. We also examine the effects of Coriolis force on the preferential aggregation of inertial particles.

Experimental Results: We have performed a suite of experiments using our in-house flow tanks in support of our theoretical and numerical analysis. These experiments involved both inertial and non-inertial particles in time-independent and time-dependent flows. Using both particle imaging velocimetry (PIV) and particle tracking velocimetry (PTV) we have investigated FTLE and LCS for a variety of flow fields and have studied the role of inertial effects, particle shape, and particle size.

Algorithms and Simulation Results:  We have developed a direct numerical simulation method, within the framework of a multi-phase Navier-Stokes code known as Paris, to perform numerical experiments on realistic, extended inertial objects with shape, finite size and density.  Codes were validated on complex 3D flows and results informed theoretical work. Separately, we have developed accurate algorithms for the machine learning of trajectories in complex and time-dependent geophysical flows (quasi-geostrophy).

The results obtained from these studies form the basis for improved understanding of how inertial and non-inertial objects are transported in geophysical fluid environments and for developing strategies that take advantage of the underlying dynamics to optimally control autonomous vehicles operating in the flow.  Outcomes from the research project were presented at conferences and seminars, and were published in refereed scientific journals and conference proceedings including SIAM Review, Chaos: An Interdisciplinary Journal of Nonlinear Science, Physics Letters A, Proceedings of the Robotics: Systems and Science (RSS) Conference, Proceedings of the International Symposium on Robotics Research (ISRR), as well as a chapter in Stochastic PDEs and Modelling of Multiscale Complex System (Interdisciplinary Mathematical Sciences: Volume 20, World Scientific).

The project supported 18 undergraduate students, 6 masters students, and a high school student. The students were taught a variety of skills, including theoretical and computational methods, reading and understanding the existing scientific literature, writing, and presenting their work. These skills will be beneficial to them in their future careers.
